        <item>
          <title>Fort McMurray residents face job uncertainty amid wildfire evacuation </title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2016/05/12/fort-mcmurray-residents-face-job-uncertainty-amid-wildfire-evacuation.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">3d925c00-bb90-417c-b806-5232910dde19</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 21:45:49 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/fort-mcmurray-residents-face-job-uncertainty-amid-wildfire-evacuation/afpae3hp.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>Some businesses, such as the Super 8 Fort McMurray, will continue to pay its employees as residents wait to return to the city. 
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            Robin Levinson King - Staff Reporter</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/fort-mcmurray-residents-face-job-uncertainty-amid-wildfire-evacuation/afpae3hp.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/fort-mcmurray-residents-face-job-uncertainty-amid-wildfire-evacuation/afpae3hp.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>The franchise-owner of the Super Motel 8 in Fort McMurray said all employees have been receiving regular pay since the wildfires.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">JONATHAN HAYWARD</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">AFP/GETTY IMAGES</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Opposition says Sophie Grégoire Trudeau is out of touch with ordinary struggles</title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2016/05/12/opposition-says-sophie-grgoire-trudeau-is-out-of-touch-with-ordinary-struggles.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">8df0717d-87e2-461e-acf2-e7d049289e61</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 20:04:24 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/opposition-says-sophie-grgoire-trudeau-is-out-of-touch-with-ordinary-struggles/sophie-gregoire-trudeau-fillactivejpg.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>Conservative MP Candice Bergen had little sympathy for Sophie Grégoire Trudeau. She said being the family of a prime minister is a difficult job that involves “a lot of sacrifices.”
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            Tonda MacCharles - Ottawa Bureau reporter</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/opposition-says-sophie-grgoire-trudeau-is-out-of-touch-with-ordinary-struggles/sophie-gregoire-trudeau-fillactivejpg.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/opposition-says-sophie-grgoire-trudeau-is-out-of-touch-with-ordinary-struggles/sophie-gregoire-trudeau-fillactivejpg.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>Sophie Grégoire Trudeau commented about needing an aide while on a trip to Quebec where she appeared as a spokesperson for Fillactive, an organization that promotes healthy activity for teenaged girls.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">Supplied photo</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">Fillactive / FitSpirit</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Brampton men bring relief to Fort McMurray firestorm evacuees</title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2016/05/12/toronto-men-bring-relief-to-fort-mcmurray-firestorm-evacuees.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">9b4abd28-4a6d-46e5-83f5-f30bd23a2177</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 19:09:51 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/toronto-men-bring-relief-to-fort-mcmurray-firestorm-evacuees/toronto-wildfire3.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>Sikh group grabs opportunity to 'give back' by driving across country with truck full of vital supplies
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            Katie Daubs - Feature Writer </author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/toronto-men-bring-relief-to-fort-mcmurray-firestorm-evacuees/toronto-wildfire3.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/toronto-men-bring-relief-to-fort-mcmurray-firestorm-evacuees/toronto-wildfire3.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>Lac La Biche Mayor Omer Moghrabi, second from left, greets members of the Singh Khalsa Sewa Club of Brampton who drove across Canada with donations for the evacuees.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">Singh Khalsa Sewa Club</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">Toronto Star</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Liberals unveil new rules to crack down on partisan government advertising</title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2016/05/12/liberals-unveil-new-rules-to-crack-down-on-partisan-government-advertising.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">1b9fd6b1-3ac2-4260-b07e-3bb59ecfa020</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 18:56:56 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/liberals-unveil-new-rules-to-crack-down-on-partisan-government-advertising/economic-action-plan-3.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>Treasury Board President Scott Brison unveiled new rules Thursday that would require any government ad campaign over $500,000 to be reviewed by the independent Advertising Standards Canada.
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            Alex Boutilier - Ottawa Bureau Reporter</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/liberals-unveil-new-rules-to-crack-down-on-partisan-government-advertising/economic-action-plan-3.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/liberals-unveil-new-rules-to-crack-down-on-partisan-government-advertising/economic-action-plan-3.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>Treasury Board President Scott Brison   tied the new rules governing the use of public funds for partisan advertising to criticisms of the previous Conservative government’s advertising, such as the ubiquitous Economic Action Plan campaigns.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">LYLE STAFFORD</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">REUTERS file photo</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Stem cell scientists update research guidelines to stress patient protection </title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2016/05/12/stem-cell-scientists-update-research-guidelines-to-stress-patient-protection.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">d90a743f-b2a2-4b12-a871-4ca6b4ef39e6</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 17:58:03 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/stem-cell-scientists-update-research-guidelines-to-stress-patient-protection/stem-cell-guidelines.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>The updated rules also oppose the marketing of unproven stem cell therapies in countries where regulations don’t exist. 
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            Sheryl Ubelacker - The Canadian Press</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/stem-cell-scientists-update-research-guidelines-to-stress-patient-protection/stem-cell-guidelines.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/stem-cell-scientists-update-research-guidelines-to-stress-patient-protection/stem-cell-guidelines.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>A global organization of scientists has released updated guidelines for research into stem cells, the so-called "holy grail" of regenerative medicine.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">Paul Sancya</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">THE ASSOCIATED PRESS file photo</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Canada now full supporter of UN Declaration on Rights of Indigenous Peoples, Bennett says</title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2016/05/12/canada-now-full-supporter-of-un-declaration-on-rights-of-indigenous-peoples-bennett-says.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">0c1e1084-edcb-4317-ac90-e672f3a19ece</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 17:56:02 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/canada-now-full-supporter-of-un-declaration-on-rights-of-indigenous-peoples-bennett-says/bennettjpg.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>Indigenous Affairs Minister Caroyln Bennett got a standing ovation from a UN forum after the announcement.
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            Bruce Cheadle - The Canadian Press</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/canada-now-full-supporter-of-un-declaration-on-rights-of-indigenous-peoples-bennett-says/bennettjpg.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/canada-now-full-supporter-of-un-declaration-on-rights-of-indigenous-peoples-bennett-says/bennettjpg.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>Minister of Indigenous and Northern Affairs Carolyn Bennett has said that Canada will implement the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous People.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">Adrian Wyld</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">THE CANADIAN PRESS</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Federal parole board studying changes to pardon fees</title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2016/05/12/federal-parole-board-studying-changes-to-pardon-fees.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">8c9d00df-1815-4a2f-9959-5b886bb46047</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 17:55:38 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/federal-parole-board-studying-changes-to-pardon-fees/ralph-goodale.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>The Parole Board of Canada quietly launched an online consultation this week asking people what they think of the $631 application charge for a criminal pardon — a fee that quadrupled under the previous Conservative government.
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            Jim Bronskill - The Canadian Press</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/federal-parole-board-studying-changes-to-pardon-fees/ralph-goodale.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/federal-parole-board-studying-changes-to-pardon-fees/ralph-goodale.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>Public Safety Minister Ralph Goodale's office says the government will review the waiting period and fee for a pardon, with a view to considering fairness, proportionality, and the role that erasing a criminal record plays in rehabilitation.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">Adrian Wyld</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">THE CANADIAN PRESS file photo</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Judge awards Ontario inmates $85,000 over lockdowns </title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2016/05/12/judge-awards-ontario-inmates-85000-over-lockdowns.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">5e606e00-88d9-4845-9a4b-b37346e146ab</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 17:24:13 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/judge-awards-ontario-inmates-85000-over-lockdowns/maplehurst.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>Maplehurst Correctional Complex inmates win damages for staffing-related lockdowns in a case that may pave the way for class-action suit.
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            Amy Dempsey - Feature Writer</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/judge-awards-ontario-inmates-85000-over-lockdowns/maplehurst.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/judge-awards-ontario-inmates-85000-over-lockdowns/maplehurst.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>At Maplehurst Correctional Complex in Milton, the units that housed the two inmates involved in the court case were locked down for 50 per cent of the time in 2014 and 2015 on average.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">Simon Wilson</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">Toronto Star file photo</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Newfoundland volunteer ousted from charity for pro-gay, pro-choice views </title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2016/05/12/newfoundland-volunteer-ousted-from-charity-for-pro-gay-pro-choice-views.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">c84cb8dd-781c-492d-88c3-e65fb6c03803</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 17:17:06 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/newfoundland-volunteer-ousted-from-charity-for-pro-gay-pro-choice-views/kay-cossar.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>The woman was sent packing from Operation Christmas Child after she refused to sign a statement of faith that denounced same-sex marriage and abortion.
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            Sue Bailey - The Canadian Press</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/newfoundland-volunteer-ousted-from-charity-for-pro-gay-pro-choice-views/kay-cossar.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/newfoundland-volunteer-ousted-from-charity-for-pro-gay-pro-choice-views/kay-cossar.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>Kay Cossar said she was "shocked" following her removal from Operation Christmas Child over her support for gay marriage and abortion "because we’re in 2016”</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">Joe Cossar</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner"></media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Nuclear safety specialists to check out radiological devices in Fort McMurray</title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2016/05/12/fort-mcmurray-to-be-inspected-by-nuclear-safety-specialists-as-precaution.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">309a18d5-2b1e-4ade-9423-973e89fc5951</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 16:32:23 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/fort-mcmurray-to-be-inspected-by-nuclear-safety-specialists-as-precaution/fort-mac-fire.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>The Canadian Nuclear Safety Commission stresses the decision to check out radiological devices following the destructive wildfire is just precautionary. 
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            The Canadian Press</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/fort-mcmurray-to-be-inspected-by-nuclear-safety-specialists-as-precaution/fort-mac-fire.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/fort-mcmurray-to-be-inspected-by-nuclear-safety-specialists-as-precaution/fort-mac-fire.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>The burned-out neighbourhood of Beacon Hill is seen in Fort McMurray, Alta., on Monday. The Nuclear Safety Commission says it got a request for assistance on Thursday from Alberta’s provincial emergency operations centre.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">JONATHAN HAYWARD</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">THE CANADIAN PRESS</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Fire crews fight hot spots in Fort McMurray as damage is assessed, plans made for cleanup</title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2016/05/12/fire-crews-fight-hot-spots-in-fort-mcmurray-as-damage-is-assessed.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">c3ad32ad-8abc-43fd-b51f-00cdab9a5c94</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 16:11:09 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/fire-crews-fight-hot-spots-in-fort-mcmurray-as-damage-is-assessed/fort-mac-damagejpg.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>Inspectors are now assessing the damage to homes in Fort McMurray as fire fighters continue to extinguish flare-ups.
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            The Canadian Press</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/fire-crews-fight-hot-spots-in-fort-mcmurray-as-damage-is-assessed/fort-mac-damagejpg.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/fire-crews-fight-hot-spots-in-fort-mcmurray-as-damage-is-assessed/fort-mac-damagejpg.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>Burned out homes are pictured in the Abasand neighbourhood of Fort McMurray. A damage assessment is now underway while fire fighters continue to put out flare-ups.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">CHRIS WATTIE</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">REUTERS</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Aboriginal issues ‘invisible’ to many Canadians, says Paul Martin</title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2016/05/12/aboriginal-issues-invisible-to-many-canadians-says-paul-martin.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">fa282c29-f398-4cac-b4bd-220fd97a70f4</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 15:56:08 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/aboriginal-issues-invisible-to-many-canadians-says-paul-martin/paulmartinjpg.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>When more Canadians grasp the challenges faced by Canada's Aboriginal Peoples, they will realize it’s unacceptable to discriminate against them, the former PM says.
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            The Canadian Press</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/aboriginal-issues-invisible-to-many-canadians-says-paul-martin/paulmartinjpg.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/aboriginal-issues-invisible-to-many-canadians-says-paul-martin/paulmartinjpg.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>Former prime minister Paul Martin says his Liberal government had child welfare services on reserves in its sights when it drafted the Kelowna accord, which was eventually abandoned by Stephen Harper’s Conservatives.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">Adrian Wyld</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">THE CANADIAN PRESS</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Most government-sponsored Syrian refugees now have housing, McCallum says </title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2016/05/12/most-government-sponsored-syrian-refugees-now-have-housing-mccallum-says.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">f8129ec1-a1da-4e81-9dae-6482444d8a9f</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 15:36:07 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/most-government-sponsored-syrian-refugees-now-have-housing-mccallum-says/john-mccallum.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>Canada's immigration minister says challenges remain in the fields of language training and jobs after announcing 98 per cent of the refugees now have permanent housing. 
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            The Canadian Press</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/most-government-sponsored-syrian-refugees-now-have-housing-mccallum-says/john-mccallum.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/most-government-sponsored-syrian-refugees-now-have-housing-mccallum-says/john-mccallum.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>Immigration Minister John McCallum says 17,300 of this year’s 25,000 government-sponsored refugees have already arrived and the remainder will be here by the end of December.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">Adrian Wyld</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">THE CANADIAN PRESS</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Quebec government introduces bill to regulate Uber and taxi industry</title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2016/05/12/quebec-government-introduces-bill-to-regulate-uber-and-taxi-industry.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">83490567-7ab7-4f8f-bdf6-747789b5d155</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 15:09:10 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/quebec-government-introduces-bill-to-regulate-uber-and-taxi-industry/quebec-uberjpg.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>Transport Minister Jacques Daoust says the bill would create a single legal framework for all taxi companies, including Uber. 
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            Alexandre Robillard - The Canadian Press</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/quebec-government-introduces-bill-to-regulate-uber-and-taxi-industry/quebec-uberjpg.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/quebec-government-introduces-bill-to-regulate-uber-and-taxi-industry/quebec-uberjpg.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>The Quebec government has introduced a new bill that aims to regulate both Uber and the taxi industry in the province.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">Jacques Boissinot</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">THE CANADIAN PRESS</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>How to create a government that’s truly for the people, by the people</title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2016/05/12/how-to-create-a-government-thats-truly-for-the-people-by-the-people.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">c1561265-5a00-424b-9141-629431ea8da0</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 14:39:00 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/how-to-create-a-government-thats-truly-for-the-people-by-the-people/digital-democracy.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>From direct engagement on budget decisions to online forums on new laws, governments are learning that success comes with more public input.
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            Allan Woods - Quebec Bureau</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/how-to-create-a-government-thats-truly-for-the-people-by-the-people/digital-democracy.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/how-to-create-a-government-thats-truly-for-the-people-by-the-people/digital-democracy.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>The Liberal party seems to agree with experts that technology is key to tapping into the sentiment of the citizenry, writes Allan Woods.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">Dreamstime</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner"> </media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Quebec education minister halts introduction of new, controversial history curriculum </title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2016/05/12/quebec-education-minister-halts-introduction-of-new-controversial-history-curriculum.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">3761cca2-738d-4270-abd6-8c0f10ea6dc0</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 14:04:52 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/quebec-education-minister-halts-introduction-of-new-controversial-history-curriculum/sebastien-proulxjpg.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>The new curriculum has been criticized for ignoring the contributions of Quebec's non-francophone populations.
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            The Canadian Press</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/quebec-education-minister-halts-introduction-of-new-controversial-history-curriculum/sebastien-proulxjpg.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/quebec-education-minister-halts-introduction-of-new-controversial-history-curriculum/sebastien-proulxjpg.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>Quebec Education and Family Minister Sebastien Proulx is refusing to sign off on a controversial new history curriculum introduced by the Parti Quebecois.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">Jacques Boissinot</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">THE CANADIAN PRESS</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>RCMP pleads not guilty to Labour Code charges in Moncton shooting</title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2016/05/12/rcmp-pleads-not-guilty-to-labour-code-charges-in-moncton-shooting.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">ea8ca4e0-58e6-40a5-94ad-ddd0677687a7</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 13:56:35 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/rcmp-pleads-not-guilty-to-labour-code-charges-in-moncton-shooting/rcmp-monctonjpg.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>The RCMP is being prosecuted for four alleged violations of the code which resulted in the deaths of three Mounties in Justin Bourque’s 2014 rampage.
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            The Canadian Press</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/rcmp-pleads-not-guilty-to-labour-code-charges-in-moncton-shooting/rcmp-monctonjpg.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/rcmp-pleads-not-guilty-to-labour-code-charges-in-moncton-shooting/rcmp-monctonjpg.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>Senior RCMP officers arrive for the sentencing of Justin Bourque in Moncton in Oct. 2014. Bourque killed three Mounties on a shooting rampage on June 4, 2014. The RCMP was subsequently charged with four Labour Code violations.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">Andrew Vaughan</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">THE CANADIAN PRESS</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Web, global travel have increased child sex abuse in tourism, study says</title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2016/05/12/web-global-travel-has-increased-child-sex-abuse-in-tourism-study-says.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">e2b8e863-220c-4c69-8840-7fefa3a1c5a1</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 09:55:02 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/web-global-travel-has-increased-child-sex-abuse-in-tourism-study-says/cpt109335437jpg.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>Data limited but suggests Canada and the U.S. are now destination countries, and that indigenous women and children are especially vulnerable.
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            Morgan Lowrie - The Canadian Press</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/web-global-travel-has-increased-child-sex-abuse-in-tourism-study-says/cpt109335437jpg.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/web-global-travel-has-increased-child-sex-abuse-in-tourism-study-says/cpt109335437jpg.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>A sign at Be Brave Ranch in Edmonton which has a therapy program that has helped child sex-abuse survivors.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author"></media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">THE CANADIAN PRESS</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Nissan buys 34 per cent stake in beleaguered Mitsubishi in ‘win-win’ deal</title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2016/05/12/nissan-buys-34-per-cent-stake-in-beleaguered-mitsubishi-in-win-win-deal.html</link>
          <guid isPermaLink="false">d68051a7-8216-48d4-a465-20657ead95ec</guid>
          
          <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 09:52:35 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/nissan-buys-34-per-cent-stake-in-beleaguered-mitsubishi-in-win-win-deal/nissanjpg.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>Nissan will invest $2.2 billion U.S. to become the top investor in Mitsubishi Motors, a company that has been recently rocked by a scandal over cheating on mileage tests.
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            Yuri Kageyama - The Associated Press</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/nissan-buys-34-per-cent-stake-in-beleaguered-mitsubishi-in-win-win-deal/nissanjpg.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/nissan-buys-34-per-cent-stake-in-beleaguered-mitsubishi-in-win-win-deal/nissanjpg.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>Nissan CEO Carlos Ghosn, left, shakes hands with Mitsubishi Motors chairman Osamu Masuko. Nissan has thrown scandal-hit Mitsubishi a lifeline with the deal, which has already seen Nissan shares drop and Mitsubishi shares rise.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">TOSHIFUMI KITAMURA</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">AFP/Getty Images</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
	            

        
        

        
        

        
        
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>RCMP to enter pleas in alleged labour code violations linked to Moncton rampage</title>
          <link>https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2016/05/12/rcmp-to-enter-pleas-in-alleged-labour-code-violations-linked-to-moncton-rampage.html</link>

          <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 09:14:25 EDT</pubDate>
          <description>
          
          	<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/rcmp-to-enter-pleas-in-alleged-labour-code-violations-linked-to-moncton-rampage/rcmp-officers.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg"/><br/>Breaches relating to police equipment, training and supervision have been alleged in the case in which three Mounties were murdered in 2014.
          
          </description>

          
          
          <author>
            The Canadian Press</author>
            

       
	            <media:content url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/rcmp-to-enter-pleas-in-alleged-labour-code-violations-linked-to-moncton-rampage/rcmp-officers.jpg.size.xxlarge.original.jpg" medium="image">
	              <media:thumbnail url="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2016/05/12/rcmp-to-enter-pleas-in-alleged-labour-code-violations-linked-to-moncton-rampage/rcmp-officers.jpg.size.xsmall.original.jpg"></media:thumbnail>
	              <media:description>A group of senior RCMP officers arriving for the sentencing of Justin Bourque, the man convicted of the murders.</media:description>
	              <media:credit role="author">Andrew Vaughan</media:credit>
	              
	              <media:credit role="owner">THE CANADIAN PRESS</media:credit>
	              
	            </media:content>
